statements.name: PROC SUMMARY
statements.description: Computes descriptive statistics for variables across all observations or within groups of observations.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: specifies the confidence level for the confidence limits.

arguments.name: CHARTYPE
arguments.description: specifies that the _TYPE_ variable contain character values.

arguments.name: CLASSDATA=
arguments.description: specifies a secondary data set that contains the combinations of class variables to analyze.

arguments.name: COMPLETETYPES
arguments.description: creates all possible combinations of class variable values.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: specifies the input data set.

arguments.name: DESCENDTYPES
arguments.description: orders the output data set by descending _TYPE_ value.

arguments.name: EXCLNPWGT
arguments.description: excludes observations with nonpositive weights from the analysis.

arguments.name: EXCLUSIVE
arguments.description: excludes from the analysis all combinations of class variable values that are not in the CLASSDATA= data set.

arguments.name: FW=
arguments.description: specifies the field width for the statistics.

arguments.name: INCAS=
arguments.description: specifies whether to allow in-CAS processing.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Use in-CAS processing. YES is the default.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Do not use in-CAS processing.

arguments.name: IDMIN
arguments.description: selects ID variables based on minimum values.

arguments.name: MAXDEC=
arguments.description: specifies the number of decimal places for the statistics.

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: uses missing values as valid values to create combinations of class variables.

arguments.name: NOLABEL
arguments.description: suppresses variable labels.

arguments.name: NONOBS
arguments.description: suppresses reporting the total number of observations for each unique combination of the class variables.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: suppresses all displayed output.

arguments.name: NOTRAP
arguments.description: disables floating point exception recovery.

arguments.name: NWAY
arguments.description: limits the output statistics to the observations with the highest _TYPE_ value.

arguments.name: ORDER=
arguments.description: orders the values of the class variables according to the specified order.

arguments.name: DATA
arguments.description: orders values according to their order in the input data set.

arguments.name: FORMATTED
arguments.description: orders values by their ascending formatted values. This order depends on your operating environment.

arguments.name: FREQ
arguments.description: orders values by descending frequency count so that levels with the most observations are listed first.

arguments.name: UNFORMATTED
arguments.description: orders values by their unformatted values, which yields the same order as PROC SORT. This order depends on your operating environment.

arguments.name: PRINT
arguments.description: displays the output.

arguments.name: PRINTALLTYPES
arguments.description: displays the analysis for all requested combinations of class variables.

arguments.name: PRINTIDVARS
arguments.description: displays the values of the ID variables.

arguments.name: QMARKERS=
arguments.description: specifies the sample size to use for the P2 quantile estimation method.

arguments.name: QMETHOD=
arguments.description: specifies the quantile estimation method.

arguments.name: OS
arguments.description: uses order statistics. This method is the same method that PROC UNIVARIATE uses.

arguments.name: P2
arguments.description: uses the PÂ² method to approximate the quantile.

arguments.name: QNTLDEF=
arguments.description: specifies the mathematical definition used to compute quantiles.

arguments.name: statistic-keyword
arguments.description: selects the statistics.

arguments.name: STACKODSOUTPUT
arguments.description: produces an ODS output object

arguments.name: SUMSIZE=
arguments.description: specifies the amount of memory to use for data summarization with class variables.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the amount of memory available in bytes, kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes, respectively. If n is 0, then PROC MEANS use the value of the SAS system option SUMSIZE=.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the amount of memory available in bytes, kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes, respectively. If n is 0, then PROC MEANS use the value of the SAS system option SUMSIZE=.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies the amount of memory available in bytes, kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes, respectively. If n is 0, then PROC MEANS use the value of the SAS system option SUMSIZE=.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: specifies the amount of memory available in bytes, kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes, respectively. If n is 0, then PROC MEANS use the value of the SAS system option SUMSIZE=.

arguments.name: MAXIMUM
arguments.description: specifies the maximum amount of memory that is available.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: specifies the maximum amount of memory that is available.

arguments.name: THREADS
arguments.description: overrides the SAS system option THREADS | NOTHREADS.

arguments.name: NOTHREADS
arguments.description: overrides the SAS system option THREADS | NOTHREADS.

arguments.name: VARDEF=
arguments.description: specifies the variance divisor.

statements.name: ATTRIB
statements.description: Associates a format, informat, label, and length with one or more variables.

arguments.name: variable-list
arguments.description: names the variables that you want to associate with the attributes.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: associates a format with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: INFORMAT=
arguments.description: associates an informat with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: associates a label with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: LENGTH=
arguments.description: specifies the length of variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: TRANSCODE=
arguments.description: specifies whether character variables can be transcoded. Use TRANSCODE=NO to suppress transcoding. Variables with TRANSCODE=NO are not returned.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: Orders the output according to the BY groups.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies the variable that the procedure uses to form BY groups. You can specify more than one variable. If you do not use the NOTSORTED option in the BY statement, then either the observations in the data set must be sorted by all the variables that you specify, or they must be indexed appropriately. Variables in a BY statement are called BY variables.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order. The observations are grouped in another way (for example, chronological order).

statements.name: CLASS
statements.description: Specifies the variables whose values define the subgroup combinations for the analysis.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies one or more variables that the procedure uses to group the data. Variables in a CLASS statement are referred to as class variables. Class variables are numeric or character. Class variables can have continuous values, but they typically have a few discrete values that define levels of the variable. You do not have to sort the data by class variables.

arguments.name: ASCENDING
arguments.description: specifies to sort the class variable levels in ascending order.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: specifies to sort the class variable levels in descending order.

arguments.name: EXCLUSIVE
arguments.description: excludes from the analysis all combinations of the class variables that are not found in the preloaded range of user-defined formats.

arguments.name: GROUPINTERNAL
arguments.description: specifies not to apply formats to the class variables when PROC MEANS groups the values to create combinations of class variables.

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: considers missing values as valid values for the class variable levels. Special missing values that represent numeric values (the letters A through Z and the underscore (_) character) are each considered as a separate value.

arguments.name: MLF
arguments.description: enables PROC MEANS to use the primary and secondary format labels for a given range or overlapping ranges to create subgroup combinations when a multilabel format is assigned to a class variable.

arguments.name: ORDER=
arguments.description: specifies the order to group the levels of the class variables in the output, where

arguments.name: DATA
arguments.description: orders values according to their order in the input data set.

arguments.name: FORMATTED
arguments.description: orders values by their ascending formatted values. This order depends on your operating environment. If no format has been assigned to a class variable, then the default format, BEST12., is used.

arguments.name: FREQ
arguments.description: orders values by descending frequency count so that levels with the most observations are listed first.

arguments.name: UNFORMATTED
arguments.description: orders values by their unformatted values, which yields the same order as PROC SORT. This order depends on your operating environment. This sort sequence is particularly useful for displaying dates chronologically.

arguments.name: PRELOADFMT
arguments.description: specifies that all formats are preloaded for the class variables.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: names one or more variables for SAS to associate with a format. You must specify at least one variable.

arguments.name: format
arguments.description: specifies the format that is listed for writing the values of the variables.

statements.name: FREQ
statements.description: Specifies a numeric variable that contains the frequency of each observation.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies a numeric variable whose value represents the frequency of the observation. If you use the FREQ statement, then the procedure assumes that each observation represents n observations, where n is the value of variable. If n is not an integer, then SAS truncates it. If n is less than 1 or is missing, then the procedure does not use that observation to calculate statistics.

statements.name: ID
statements.description: Includes additional variables in the output data set.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: identifies one or more variables from the input data set whose maximum values for groups of observations PROC MEANS includes in the output data set.

statements.name: LABEL
statements.help:
LABEL  variable-1 = 'text-string' < ...variable-n = 'text-string'>;
LABEL  variable-1 = ' ' < ...variable-n=â â>; | variable-1 = < ...variable-n= >;

arguments.name: text-string
arguments.description: specifies a label of up to 256 bytes.
removes a label from a variable. Enclose a single blank space in quotation marks to remove an existing label. You can remove labels from multiple variables in a single LABEL statement:

statements.name: OUTPUT
statements.description: Writes statistics to a new SAS data set.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: names the new output data set. If SAS-data-set does not exist, then PROC MEANS creates it. If you omit OUT=, then the data set is named DATAn, where n is the smallest integer that makes the name unique.

arguments.name: statistic-keyword
arguments.description: specifies which statistic to store in the output data set. The available statistic keywords are

arguments.name: variable-list
arguments.description: specifies the names of one or more numeric analysis variables whose statistics you want to store in the output data set.

arguments.name: names
arguments.description: specifies one or more names for the variables in the output data set that contain the analysis variable statistics. The first name contains the statistic for the first analysis variable; the second name contains the statistic for the second analysis variable; and so on.

arguments.name: IDGROUP
arguments.description: combines the features and extends the ID statement, the IDMIN option in the PROC statement, and the MAXID and MINID options in the OUTPUT statement to create an OUT= data set that identifies multiple extreme values.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: specifies the selection criteria to determine the extreme values of one or more input data set variables specified in variable-list. Use MIN to determine the minimum extreme value and MAX to determine the maximum extreme value.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: specifies the selection criteria to determine the extreme values of one or more input data set variables specified in variable-list. Use MIN to determine the minimum extreme value and MAX to determine the maximum extreme value.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: specifies that the OUT= data set contains values from the last observation (or the last n observations, if n is specified). If you do not specify LAST, then the OUT= data set contains values from the first observation (or the first n observations, if n is specified). The OUT= data set might contain several observations because in addition to the value of the last (first) observation, the OUT= data set contains values from the last (first) observation of each subgroup level that is defined by combinations of class variable values.

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: specifies that missing values be used in selection criteria.

arguments.name: OBS
arguments.description: includes an _OBS_ variable in the OUT= data set that contains the number of the observation in the input data set where the extreme value was found.

arguments.name: [n]
arguments.description: specifies the number of extreme values for each variable in id-variable-list to include in the OUT= data set. PROC MEANS creates n new variables and uses the suffix _n to create the variable names, where n is a sequential integer from 1 to n.

arguments.name: (id-variable-list)
arguments.description: identifies one or more input data set variables whose values PROC MEANS includes in the OUT= data set. PROC MEANS determines which observations to generate by the selection criteria that you specify (MIN, MAX, and LAST).

arguments.name: names
arguments.description: specifies one or more names for variables in the OUT= data set.

arguments.name: MAXID
arguments.description: specifies that one or more identification variables be associated with the maximum values of the analysis variables.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: identifies the numeric analysis variable whose maximum values PROC MEANS determines. PROC MEANS can determine several maximum values for a variable because, in addition to the overall maximum value, subgroup levels, which are defined by combinations of class variables values, also have maximum values.

arguments.name: id-variable-list
arguments.description: identifies one or more variables whose values identify the observations with the maximum values of the analysis variable.

arguments.name: names
arguments.description: specifies the names for new variables that contain the values of the identification variable associated with the maximum value of each analysis variable.

arguments.name: MINID
arguments.description: see the description of maximum-id-specification. This option behaves in exactly the same way, except that PROC MEANS determines the minimum values instead of the maximum values.

arguments.name: AUTOLABEL
arguments.description: specifies that PROC MEANS appends the statistic name to the end of the variable label. If an analysis variable has no label, then PROC MEANS creates a label by appending the statistic name to the analysis variable name.

arguments.name: AUTONAME
arguments.description: specifies that PROC MEANS creates a unique variable name for an output statistic when you do not assign the variable name in the OUTPUT statement. This action is accomplished by appending to the statistic-keyword to the end of the input variable name from which the statistic was derived.

arguments.name: KEEPLEN
arguments.description: specifies that statistics in the output data set inherit the length of the analysis variable that PROC MEANS uses to derive them.

arguments.name: LEVELS
arguments.description: includes a variable named _LEVEL_ in the output data set. This variable contains a value from 1 to n that indicates a unique combination of the values of class variables (the values of _TYPE_ variable).

arguments.name: NOINHERIT
arguments.description: specifies that the variables in the output data set that contain statistics do not inherit the attributes (label and format) of the analysis variables that are used to derive them.

arguments.name: WAYS
arguments.description: includes a variable named _WAY_ in the output data set. This variable contains a value from 1 to the maximum number of class variables that indicates how many class variables PROC MEANS combines to create the TYPE value.

statements.name: TYPES
statements.description: Identifies which of the possible combinations of class variables to generate.

arguments.name: request
arguments.description: specifies which of the 2 to the k 2k combinations of class variables PROC MEANS uses to create the types, where k k is the number of class variables. A request includes one class variable name, several class variable names separated by asterisks, or ().

statements.name: VAR
statements.description: Identifies the analysis variables and their order in the results.

statements.name: WAYS
statements.description: Specifies the number of ways to make unique combinations of class variables.

arguments.name: list
arguments.description: specifies one or more integers that define the number of class variables to combine to form all the unique combinations of class variables. For example, you can specify 2 for all possible pairs and 3 for all possible triples. The list can be specified in the following ways: â¢ m â¢ m1 m2 â¦ mn â¢ m1,m2,â¦,mn â¢ m TO n <BY increment> â¢ m1,m2 TO m3 <BY increment>, m4

statements.name: WEIGHT
statements.description: Specifies weights for analysis variables in the statistical calculations. You can use a WEIGHT statement and a FREQ statement in the same step of any procedure that supports both statements.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies a numeric variable whose values weight the values of the analysis variables. The values of the variable do not have to be integers.

statements.name: WHERE
statements.description: Subsets the input data set by specifying certain conditions that each observation must meet before it is available for processing.

arguments.name: where-expression
arguments.description: is an arithmetic or logical expression that generally consists of a sequence of operands and operators.

arguments.name: logical-operator
arguments.description: can be AND, AND NOT, OR, or OR NOT.
